name: Introduction to Psychology

learningoutcomes: A. You answer questions in a multiple-choice knowledge test demonstrating that you can reproduce and understand the basics of psychology. You demonstrate that you can analyze the behavior of individuals and groups within their social environment using case studies. B. You conduct a short interview with a fellow student, demonstrating that you can: 1. Use psychological literature to formulate questions about everyday behavior in order to identify protective and risk factors. 2. Possess the communication skills required to conduct an interview with an adult, including a professional opening and closing.

name: Grief and Loss
shortdescription: Grief & loss, palliative care & reasoning, trauma, cultural diversity
description: This module focuses on grief and loss from various perspectives, including palliative care. Themes such as oncology can be included (the nursing field requests an elective module in oncology) and can be explored interdisciplinarily, highlighting how different disciplines can jointly contribute to a palliative approach. In addition, the module addresses loss in a broader sense—such as parental divorce, fleeing one’s homeland, death, physical functioning, and friendships/relationships—aimed at adults as well as individuals aged 0–25, in which grief plays a role in development. From the professional field (nursing), there is a clear need for a module that pays attention to care related to oncology.

learningoutcomes: The student coordinates and (partially) independently carries out the palliative care process, individually and collaboratively, for high- and medium-complexity care recipients within the care setting, based on the process of palliative reasoning. The student understands, analyzes, and applies complex concepts and approaches to grief and loss in various contexts, at both individual and group levels. The student can design and implement interventions to promote resilience and well-being during the grieving process. The student critically reflects on their own values and attitudes in relation to supporting others experiencing grief and loss.

shortdescription: Personal development, activism, engagement, social impact, collaboration
description: De Tussenruimte represents (1) trans- and interdisciplinary collaboration to (2) advance societal challenges through co-creation and (3) strengthen the connection between education and research. content: De Tussenruimte represents (1) trans- and interdisciplinary collaboration to (2) advance societal challenges through co-creation and (3) strengthen the connection between education and research. This is always done from (4) the personal engagement of participants (student/staff/organisation/resident).
learningoutcomes: Engagement, activating and co-creating with a community, and critical reflection. You explore the theme of Broad Prosperity and new entrepreneurship and jointly develop a conceptual model based on knowledge and experiences gained in various ways. You present yourself both as an individual and from your own discipline. You make your learning process explicit and connect yourself substantively and relationally with others in the community (forming groups or collaborations). Based on the conceptual model and your personal motivation, you define your own challenge for this module. You conduct an environmental and stakeholder analysis. You take action, for example by entering the neighbourhood and engaging in conversations with people who may play a role in your challenge. You create experiences, gain inspiration and deepen your research based on new questions and insights. You further clarify your learning process and refine your challenge. You actively approach stakeholders to form a coalition of the willing with community members, organisations and/or citizens who support your challenge and are willing to commit to a shared ambition. Together with the coalition of the willing, you explore ideas to give shape to this ambition. You experiment or inspire on a small scale with your ideas to realise outcomes and create impact. In short, through interaction with others, you initiate a movement. You creatively demonstrate the impact you have made. You ensure that the movement initiated with the coalition of the willing can continue. You facilitate knowledge sharing, organise follow-up actions and assign responsibilities to the appropriate partners to create ownership. You identify limitations in your own knowledge and capacity for action and critically reflect on issues and processes in this context with the aim of recognising and adjusting personal development, collaboration, interaction with others and your own role within it. In doing so, you contribute to knowledge development and dissemination in the field of Broad Prosperity and new entrepreneurship. You account for your actions based on evidence and relevant literature.

description: In this international and multidisciplinary minor, you will explore the possibilities of biobased technologies, business development and sustainable entrepreneurship. The core of the minor consists of a multidisciplinary group project carried out for a client (a governmental organisation or a company).
content: In this international and multidisciplinary minor, you will explore the possibilities of biobased technologies, business development and sustainable entrepreneurship. The core of the minor consists of a multidisciplinary group project carried out for a client (a governmental organisation or a company).
learningoutcomes: (Biobased) circular value chains: you work on a multidisciplinary group project for a client (governmental organisation or company) that aims to become more sustainable or to (further) develop and implement a biobased and/or circular technology. You deliver a technical concept and a business plan for the client, integrating marketing, finance and technology. CO2-neutral cities: together with your group, you work on a selected city and learn how to make it climate neutral and how to convince relevant stakeholders to support your ideas. International biobased challenge: you collaborate with Brazilian students on a biobased challenge for a Brazilian company, learning to work effectively in an international and intercultural context under time pressure. Your world, future and purpose: you explore your personal qualities, talents and entrepreneurial ambitions in order to grow individually and as a team, both personally and professionally.

name: Avans Incubator NLQF6, 30 + 15 EC
shortdescription: Entrepreneurship, tailor-made support, growth, gateway to ecosystem, community
description: Avans Incubator is the place where students from any higher education programme can accelerate their own venture. Avans Incubator offers you the opportunity to turn your idea into a business, or to give your existing company a serious boost. It is the starting point for entrepreneurs within the West Brabant start-up ecosystem.
content: Avans Incubator is the place where students from any higher education programme can accelerate their own venture. Avans Incubator offers you the opportunity to turn your idea into a business, or to give your existing company a serious boost. It is the starting point for entrepreneurs within the West Brabant start-up ecosystem.
learningoutcomes: 1. The student creates a vision and value proposition for an organisation; 2. The student develops an enterprise based on the five key elements: Customer, Product, Business Case, Team, and Finance/Impact; 3. Entrepreneurial mindset: identifying ideas and opportunities, mobilising resources, and taking action.

name: Digital Nomads NLQF6, 30 + 15 EC
shortdescription: Entrepreneurship, travel, innovation, personal learning plan
description: Developing (digital) skills to enable entrepreneurship in a rapidly changing world, using the latest technologies and innovations. This takes place in an international setting (with preferred international hubs) and is location-independent.
content: Developing (digital) skills to enable entrepreneurship in a rapidly changing world, using the latest technologies and innovations. This takes place in an international setting (with preferred international hubs) and is location-independent.
learningoutcomes: Students are able to effectively apply entrepreneurial skills and knowledge to start, manage, and grow successful businesses, with attention to sustainability and ethics. This learning outcome emphasizes the importance of both practical and conceptual aspects of entrepreneurship. Students will not only acquire the necessary skills to establish and lead a business, but also develop an understanding of sustainability challenges and ethical considerations within the entrepreneurial domain. By achieving this learning outcome, students will be able to create value responsibly and contribute to economic development.

name: Branding: Personal Branding
shortdescription: Self-awareness, higher purpose (Ikigai), personal development, personal brand
description: Clarifying who you are, what you stand for, what you are good at, what you love, what the world needs (fellow students, colleagues, clients and everyone around you), and what you can be paid for. Building meaningful connections, being of value, and being sought after for what you want to be recognized for.
content: Clarifying who you are, what you stand for, what you are good at, what you love, what the world needs (fellow students, colleagues, clients and everyone around you), and what you can be paid for. Building meaningful connections, being of value, and being sought after for what you want to be recognized for.
learningoutcomes: 1. The student creates a personal development plan based on their personal IKIGAI, in which personal history (roots), values, and talents come together in 2–3 development goals and an action plan, enabling the student to take concrete steps toward developing their Personal Brand. 2. The student achieves personal and professional growth by following the IKIGAI-based personal development plan according to the PDCA cycle*, contributing to focused and continuous development into a Personal Brand. 3. The student creates a personal, professional, and distinctive Personal Brand, enabling the student to clearly differentiate themselves.

name: Branding: Strategic Brand Management
shortdescription: Branding, brands, image, identity, positioning, concept, social entrepreneurship
description: Contributing to a better world through brands. In a changing world, making a meaningful contribution as a brand. Does your brand take social responsibility and give meaning to the world around it? You will learn how to translate the SDGs into practical applications and how brands can create concrete connections with society.
content: Contributing to a better world through brands. In a changing world, making a meaningful contribution as a brand. Does your brand take social responsibility and give meaning to the world around it? You will learn how to translate the SDGs into practical applications and how brands can create concrete connections with society.
learningoutcomes: 1. Interpreting key theories and the latest developments in the field of branding, enabling you to provide appropriate advice on building meaningful and future-proof brands. 2. Developing a brand plan in the role of brand consultant, enabling you to define an appropriate brand strategy for a meaningful brand based on thorough analysis.

name: International Business Operations

shortdescription: International project management, stakeholder management, intercultural collaboration
description: This module focuses on international project management and stakeholder engagement in complex, intercultural contexts.
content: International project management and stakeholder engagement in an international and intercultural context.
learningoutcomes: Develop a stakeholder engagement policy, apply ethics in international business, conduct international negotiations, manage competing interests, and apply lobbying and advocacy strategies.

name: Trust the *&^% Process
shortdescription: Play, failure, experimentation, discovery, personal exploration, anti-design, reflection, dealing with uncertainty and discomfort, trusting your own process, seeing opportunities, environmental sensitivity
description: By ridiculing, caricaturing and exaggerating the design process, students discover the value of the process itself. A key challenge is explicitly involving and guiding clients from non-design backgrounds through this process.
content: By ridiculing, caricaturing and exaggerating the design process, students discover the value of the process itself and learn how to involve clients from non-design contexts.
learningoutcomes: Develop trust in the value of one’s own design process and be able to demonstrate and communicate the power of this process to non-design professionals.

name: Tutorial Club

name: Artistic Entrepreneurship for Art, Design and Performance
shortdescription: Personal branding, freelance entrepreneurship, networking, professional presentation, portfolio development, rights and obligations as a creative professional
description: As a creative professional, there is a strong chance that you will become a freelancer after graduation, especially if you want to stay in control of your own work. But how do you position yourself and your creative work in the market? In this module, you will learn the knowledge and skills needed for entrepreneurship. Topics include personal branding, presenting your work, building a professional network, filing tax returns and applying for subsidies. You will learn how to determine the value of your work, how to position yourself professionally, and how to acquire assignments. You will also have the opportunity to exchange experiences with creative entrepreneurs from the professional field and learn from their real-world practice beyond the educational environment.
content: This module focuses on entrepreneurial skills for creative makers, including personal branding, professional presentation, networking, portfolio development, and understanding legal and financial responsibilities such as copyright, taxes and subsidies.
learningoutcomes: The student learns how to position and brand themselves as a creative professional within a chosen market, as preparation for freelance entrepreneurship, and gains insight into the legal, financial and professional conditions required to operate as an independent maker.

name: Avans Innovative Studio – Foundation
shortdescription: Personal development, interdisciplinary collaboration, innovation, prototyping, valorization
description: During this module, you will learn which knowledge and skills are needed for entrepreneurship. Topics include personal branding, presenting your work, building a professional network, filing tax returns and applying for subsidies.
content: This module focuses on developing entrepreneurial and innovative skills through interdisciplinary collaboration, experimentation, prototyping and value creation.
learningoutcomes: The student demonstrates personal growth across six competencies. The student is able to create and experiment in a domain-specific and interdisciplinary manner, leading to innovative forms of multiple and sustainable value creation.

name: Business Innovation
shortdescription: Innovation, innovation methods, casework, business models, responsible innovation
description: In this module you will learn what innovation is and which innovation methods exist. You will learn the fundamentals of organizations and work on developing sustainable and responsible innovations. By the end of the module, you will be able to apply the Responsible Business Innovation Canvas. If you succeed, you will have a solid foundation to start your journey as an innovator.
content: This module focuses on understanding innovation and innovation methods, organizational fundamentals and the development of sustainable and responsible business innovations using the Responsible Business Innovation Canvas.
learningoutcomes: As a business innovator, the student develops an innovation pathway for a client. At the end of the module, the student designs this pathway based on knowledge of innovation fundamentals, organizations, organizational theory and innovation methods. The student is able to analyse complex challenges in order to make well-informed decisions during the design and implementation of an innovation, taking into account organizational innovation capacity, sustainability, ethical and societal considerations, as well as the feasibility, desirability and viability of the innovation design.

name: Business Innovation Design for Innovation
shortdescription: Design thinking, visualization, fundamentals, branding
description: In the Design for Innovation module, you work as a designer on solving a problem. Together with your design team, you complete design assignments, referred to as ‘challenges’. Each challenge focuses on different areas within the design discipline.
content: In the Design for Innovation module, you work as a designer on solving a problem. Together with your design team, you complete design assignments, referred to as ‘challenges’. Each challenge emphasizes different areas within the design discipline.
learningoutcomes: As a business innovator and creative explorer, the student develops innovative products within the innovation process. By the end of this module, the student is able to generate ideas (diverge), challenge and select ideas (converge), visualize concepts through sketches or by building prototypes, and present ideas and concepts to users and clients. The student can apply creative design and making methods to create products, services and brands that align with the needs and wishes of the target group. The student is able to set up, execute, adapt and critically reflect on a design process, and apply it within an innovation project.

name: Business Innovation Research for Innovation
shortdescription: Research for innovation, prototype testing, implementation research, concept testing
description: In this module, you learn to experiment with research methods that help you realize an innovation. Within an innovation process, several phases can be identified in which research plays a key role. You learn (innovative) research approaches to uncover the problem behind the problem, further develop solution directions, and realize a viable solution.
content: In this module, you learn to experiment with research methods that support the realization of innovation. Throughout the innovation process, research contributes to different phases. You apply innovative research methods to identify underlying problems, advance solution directions, and successfully implement an innovation.
learningoutcomes: As a business innovator, the student conducts research in all phases of an innovation project. By the end of this module, the student is able to make well-founded choices regarding research methods in each phase of the innovation process. During the exploratory phase, the student formulates relevant research questions and selects appropriate research methods. The student then maps both the current and desired situations by applying the chosen methods, after which a systematic concept test is designed and executed. Based on critical analysis and research, the student weighs perspectives of internal stakeholders and develops a feasible implementation strategy. The student is able to design, execute, adapt and critically reflect on a research process and apply it within an innovation project. Finally, the student reflects on the value of the applied research methods and the quality of their execution, contributing to more successful innovations.

shortdescription: sustainability, footprint, environmental impact, spatial design, biobased construction
description: This elective module focuses on spatial design in the transition towards biobased construction. Students explore the use of rapidly renewable materials, supply chain integration with biobased material producers, and strategies to reduce—and ultimately reverse—the environmental impact of material use within the built environment.
content: This elective module focuses on spatial design in the transition towards biobased construction. learningoutcomes: Students are able to design spatial solutions within the built environment that contribute to CO2 reduction or CO2 negativity. They can apply principles of biobased construction, assess material-related environmental impact, and integrate sustainability and circularity considerations into spatial design concepts.

name: Module 4.1/4.2: Disruptive Events: Migration Policy and Practice
shortdescription: migration, resilience, crisis response, risk management, policy and governance
description: In this module, students explore one of the major disruptive issues affecting Europe in recent years: migration. The module focuses on governance and migration policy, radicalization and terrorism, ethics, and resilience in times of crisis. Through two international field trips, students conduct participatory research in refugee camps (such as Athens, Calais, or Palermo) to gain first-hand insight into migration practices and policy implementation.
content: In this module, students explore one of the major disruptive issues affecting Europe in recent years: migration. The module focuses on governance and migration policy, radicalization and terrorism, ethics, and resilience in times of crisis. Through two international field trips, students conduct participatory research in refugee camps (such as Athens, Calais, or Palermo) to gain first-hand insight into migration practices and policy implementation.
learningoutcomes: Students are able to analyse migration as a disruptive societal phenomenon by critically assessing migration policies, governance structures, and ethical considerations. They can apply participatory research methods in an international context, reflect on resilience and crisis response practices, and translate field-based insights into policy-oriented and practice-oriented recommendations.

Flooding and drought are global challenges that increasingly affect the liveability of cities. Students collaborate with an international peer team in Vietnam to develop sustainable, climate-adaptive and flood-resilient solutions for urbanized areas.
content: An interdisciplinary team of students (urban planners, architects and civil/water managers) works together to address the growing threat of water in inhabited areas worldwide. They create and test innovative and sustainable design concepts in which water is treated as a guiding and structuring element. Students analyse stakeholders and their interests, translate design requirements into spatial, architectural and water-related proposals, apply principles of the Dutch approach to water management in an international context, and make well-founded design decisions related to climate change and sustainability.

shortdescription: Control systems, mechatronics, rapid prototyping
description: During this elective module, a group of students works on designing and building a robot (for example, a mine-clearing robot). The robot and its tooling should be produced as much as possible using 3D-printed components.
content: During this elective module, a group of students works on designing and building a robot (for example, a mine-clearing robot). The robot and its tooling should be produced as much as possible using 3D-printed components.
learningoutcomes:
Example project involving the construction of a mine-clearing robot:

1. Detailed design (6 EC)
The student designs a robot that can locate and pick up a mine without triggering it. Due to the short duration of the elective module, a rapid design process is used, with guidance provided.

2. Prototype (6 EC)
The design is realized as a prototype. For feasibility, a scale model is used. Multiple materials are applied. Additional knowledge of 3D printing is required to print in different materials. The result is ultimately tested during a competition day.

3. Energy management (3 EC)
The robot must autonomously locate the mine. It must be able to drive over rough terrain, stop at the correct position, and carefully pick up and transport the mine to a location where it can be safely neutralized. All of this must be done with a limited energy supply, requiring knowledge of battery technology.

name: Cross Media & User Experience
shortdescription: cross-media, user journey, storytelling, future, IoT
description:
In the CMUX module, you learn how a person navigates a path through the jungle of different media. This goes beyond technical and design aspects to include experience and emotion. Which touchpoints do you encounter, what options do you have, and how do they influence, for example, a funnel? Think of a city festival: ticket scanning, crowd control, and managing food and beverage services. Or a walking app with offline checkpoints where you can meet fellow walkers.

Automation techniques are required (mobile apps, websites, POS systems), as well as visual designs (posters, UIs), but above all, designing the overall journey experience is the main learning objective.

One elective module with a shared platform (site-specific, situated learning environment) is provided, where participants can choose from different assignments. These assignments can complement and strengthen each other.

name: Robotic AI Interfaces - option 1*
shortdescription: artificial intelligence, physical space, problem solving, research through making, real-world practice
description: Within the elective module “Robotic AI Interfaces”, students work in teams of five using the Design Thinking method to carry out an exploratory, practice-oriented research project addressing the question: “What is needed to successfully deploy robotic AI interfaces in practice?”. To ensure the results can be effectively applied in real-world contexts, the module uses situated design methods. These methods aim to avoid assumptions in design and instead rely solely on substantiated research results from realistic practice situations. The final outcome is a proof of concept that has been validated and tested in practice.
content: Within the elective module “Robotic AI Interfaces”, students work in teams of five using the Design Thinking method to carry out an exploratory, practice-oriented research project addressing the question: “What is needed to successfully deploy robotic AI interfaces in practice?”. To ensure the results can be effectively applied in real-world contexts, the module uses situated design methods. These methods aim to avoid assumptions in design and instead rely solely on substantiated research results from realistic practice situations. The final outcome is a proof of concept that has been validated and tested in practice.
learningoutcomes:
Learning Outcome 1:
You contribute from your own area of expertise to the development of a proof of concept that, through a robotic interface, addresses a real-world problem provided by practice. The robotic interface makes use of natural interaction and minimizes the use of text and screens. The robotic interface is tested in a real-world practice setting.

Learning Outcome 2:
You explore the context of a real-world problem through research through making and are able to translate results into findings that contribute to the development of a proof of concept. This research through making is carried out in a realistic, situated context of the practical problem. You do this by mapping where, when, how, and for whom or what a robotic interface can be deployed in a real-world situation.

Learning Outcome 3:
You collaborate in a team to develop a proof of concept for a real-world problem. Within the team, you set personal development goals and work throughout the project to achieve them. You are able to articulate and substantiate your contributions to the team and your own learning moments. At the start of the project, you write a project plan that includes collaboration agreements and a division of team roles, as well as a work schedule. During the project, you collaborate professionally with fellow students under the supervision of a project lecturer. You provide feedback to group members and reflect on the progress of the project, your own contribution, and your personal development. You communicate group progress regularly to the client in the prescribed manner. You conclude the project by transferring the product to the client, taking the audience into account and ensuring a clear and well-structured handover.

name: Future-Oriented Production Line
shortdescription: Maintenance, production line, optimization, real-life
description:
During this elective module, a group of students works on a real-life production line from industry. To optimize this production line, students first analyze the current situation. This analysis reveals improvement points that can be optimized.

Based on the analysis, improvements are implemented and actually put into practice. Improvements may focus on technical aspects (mechanical, electrical, control systems) to reduce maintenance needs, changeover times, or malfunctions, or on organizational aspects (material supply, ease of operation, fault tolerance, change management) to increase added value.

An important part of this optimization is the application of TPM (Total Productive Manufacturing/Management).

An important part of this optimization is the application of TPM (Total Productive Manufacturing/Management).
learningoutcomes:
Learning Outcome 1:
The student group analyzes the production line in such a way that data is generated or collected to serve as input for optimization. This includes data for OEE, as well as data originating from maintenance teams (such as tribological data from bearings).

Learning Outcome 2:
The data from the production line analysis forms the starting point for optimization. Students work on improving the production line in various ways and across different domains. This may include providing advice for the production environment, designing an improved gripper, or implementing optimizations in the control system, depending on the generated data.

Learning Outcome 3:
By applying the principles of the TPM approach, students learn to identify problems and develop or apply solutions in a machine-driven environment to improve the uptime of a machine or production line. Based on the pillars of TPM, the student can substantiate that the production line benefits from the optimization.

learningoutcomes:
Learning Outcome 1:
The student investigates different forms of optimization and is able to apply these systemically within a design.

Learning Outcome 2 (2nd-year students):
Starting product: an existing product that must be optimized in terms of mass, stiffness, etc. Part of the optimization includes delivering a Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) and a Total Cost of Ownership (TCO).

Starting product: a newly developed product that must be optimized from the outset in terms of mass, stiffness, etc. Part of the optimization includes delivering a Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) and a Total Cost of Ownership (TCO).

Deliverable: a 3D model and a functional prototype incorporating the above elements.

name: AI Translator
shortdescription: Translation, AI, ethics, social_impact, communication
description:
Artificial intelligence, or AI, is rapidly becoming more important and increasingly present in our world. Breakthroughs are happening one after another, and AI systems influence nearly every domain: from social media filters, smart chatbots (GPT), health-tech and the energy transition to Netflix recommendations…
At the same time, there are serious threats we are confronted with that challenge our work, violate our privacy, discriminate against groups, and include cases where things went wrong… to name just a few: the childcare benefits scandal, Cambridge Analytica, the social assistance affair…
People who design AI systems often look at them from a purely technical perspective and overlook the societal or individual consequences of these systems. There is much more involved than solving a technical problem—how do you involve people and business processes in this?

There is an urgent need to translate the technical aspects into real-world implementation. We need people who can act as a liaison and bridge the gap between the knowledge generated by AI systems and the domain knowledge of users.
As an AI Translator, you translate complex real-world situations to AI experts and data scientists, guide the process in terms of content, and ensure that the results are embedded in practice.
You determine not only what is possible and permitted (the technological and legal question), but also what is desirable and responsible (the ethical and societal question). You translate this into business cases.

learningoutcomes:
1. Contributing to the world of tomorrow
You feel the necessity and urgency to contribute creatively to a societal issue in collaboration with other disciplines.
From your own discipline and from a specific professional context, you contribute together with other disciplines (with perspectives, methods, activities, products, services, etc.) to creating a new response to a societal issue.
You investigate the perspectives and ambitions of stakeholders in this societal issue, such as citizens, entrepreneurs, NGOs and governments, in order to mobilize them.
You make use of your strengths as a maker and the different roles you can fulfill in the various phases.

2. Taking a role in interdisciplinary collaboration
You explore your own role and that of others in an interdisciplinary collaboration in order to achieve a complete and enjoyable collaboration.
You reflect on the value of your own role and that of others, identify gaps in group composition and dynamics, and take the lead by proposing interventions.
You identify strengths and weaknesses of the collaboration process and, based on these experiences, you can make well-founded choices for your own role in future collaborations.
In doing so, you use a model that identifies crucial competencies for interdisciplinary collaboration, such as critical thinking, reflection, giving and receiving feedback, perseverance, perspective shifting, open-mindedness, etc.

3. Developing research skills
From a focused interest and an actively curious attitude, you delve into a societal issue with the aim of setting something in motion.
You conduct research in a systematic and traceable manner and with an appropriate level of depth into societal issues in order to develop/provide effective responses.
You make use of practical data, different stakeholder perspectives, and existing knowledge from practice-oriented research such as Centres of Expertise.
This includes identifying what knowledge is already available, what is missing, and how the latter can be obtained.

name: Writing for Confidence
shortdescription: creative writing, storytelling skills, genres, hybrid forms, visual art
description:
The Story You Want to Tell – Writing for Confidence

How does one distill the ideas that lurk in the back (or front) of their minds into WORK. Work of resonance, work that one can say… yes, this is the story I want to tell. For many emerging makers, the struggle to find one’s voice—to hear themselves as authentic, clear, and resonant with the scope of their passions—starts with a basic lack of confidence in what you want to tell, how you want to tell it, and how you can share it. Within “The Story You Want to Tell,” we work with young creatives who are seeking a route to confidence, using writing as a catalyst and grounding force that they can lean on throughout their careers. We focus on helping students feel confident through a practice-driven course, where they see the progress they are making and return to their core studies with a better idea of who they are, what they are here to tell, and maybe even how.
This is a lab, with exposure to new media, new forms of writing and making, with language and communication (textual and visual) at the center.

name: Inclusive Collaboration Without Losers
shortdescription: corporate anthropology, environmental communication, Deep Democracy, organizational culture, change, communication, connection, polarization, leadership
description: In all major (and often also smaller) challenges, we need other parties to address them. At the same time, no one is trained to be a ‘collaborator’: we often do it on the side and rely heavily on feeling, intuition, and experience. How do you navigate within an organization? How should you collaborate in and with a team? What are the key patterns in collaborative settings? And how can you consciously work with these patterns from your own role?\nBuilding connection across differences. Learn how people shape culture and how culture shapes people. Challenge yourself to look differently at people and teams.\nBased on the Deep Democracy method, you ensure that the wisdom of the entire group is utilized. You bring the undercurrent (the collective wisdom) to the surface in order to unlock the potential of each individual and strengthen the sense of group cohesion. Truly listening and giving space to the ‘minority’ is an essential part of this. You can only build a team based on interaction and dialogue! No meetings, hearings, or formal gatherings, but encounters in which you share the right perspectives with one another and make decisions together.

name: Art & Activism
shortdescription: personal activism, critical reflection, search for form, radical nuance, slowing down, laboratory, refinement, counter-narrative
description:
Personal Activism is specifically aimed at students who critically observe the world and have the desire to use their artistic practice to contribute to meaningful change. How do art, the world, and personal activism relate to one another? And how can you, as a young artist, contribute to meaningful change?

As a student, in addition to the structured program, you take time for independent exploration of nuances in image, material, and form. This can be done both individually and collectively.

Because personal engagement is the starting point for these students, the emphasis of this module lies on the search for form.

Students work across different disciplines and media (such as performance, autonomous art, video, photography, etc.). They repeatedly develop the same content in different forms and refine it. The search for radical nuance in personal engagement ultimately takes shape through refinement of imagery, with the aim that personal activism can activate others.

Using elements such as humor, counter-narratives, and ambiguity, forms are explored and developed in which radical nuance can manifest publicly. This activist approach requires that all participating students actually share the various forms of radical nuance in the appropriate context.

From an academic perspective, attention is given to the importance of imagination in relation to activism.

name: Stop Motion
shortdescription: graphic novel, interactive, webtoon, storytelling, illustration
description:

You explore your role within a stop-motion production team and collaboratively develop a story in which multiple characters can play a role. You build puppets and sets to scale, making use of the academy’s well-equipped workshops (such as the woodworking shop and 3D print shop). You take animation classes, discover what is important for storytelling in stop motion, and experiment with appropriate design and material use. Together with your team, you go through the entire process from storyboard to shooting and finally to the premiere.

This minor is for students who enjoy storytelling and working with analogue techniques, and for anyone who wants to experience the full production process of a stop-motion film. And when else during your studies do you get the chance to spend half a year working on an animation?

name: Graphic Novel
shortdescription: creative writing, storytelling skills, genres, hybrid forms, visual art
description:
A graphic novel is a comic with a more mature character in terms of theme, depth and narrative. It is sometimes fictional, but it can also be (auto)biographical in nature. You could see it as the literary side of visual storytelling, with real stories about real people leading real lives in a real world. You will rarely find long-running series or franchises for graphic novel characters, unlike superheroes.

In the programme of this minor at St. Joost School of Art & Design, you follow the entire design methodology of a graphic novel, from your first ideas to the final production. You are guided by lecturers from the St. Joost art academy. The focus of the supervision is on the quality and development of both the narrative and the visual aspects. Modern (online) forms such as the interactive graphic novel and webtoons are also covered.

You bring a proposal in the form of an idea, concept, or preferably already some form of script and preliminary studies, possibly even thumbnails for your graphic novel. This can be an original story you want to tell in comic form, or an existing story that you find appealing to visualise. Both fiction and non-fiction are possible.

name: Write Loud
shortdescription: digital and analogue drawing skills, observation, imagination, composition and image construction
description:
The creative writing minor Write LOUD at St. Joost School of Art & Design is designed for students who want to establish strong storytelling skills in written form. It helps students further define, articulate and expand their practice through creative writing.

In this course, you will explore what a writing discipline can offer a developing visual or media practice. This creative writing practice takes a form, genre and approach that suits you as a creator, with an emphasis on the programme’s unique perspective at the intersection of literature, Photography, Film and Digital media, through an interdisciplinary collaboration with Watershed Production House.

This minor is particularly geared towards students with a solid background in using imagery to convey meaning. It is well suited to students with a background in or affinity for Visual Arts, Media Production, Design, Illustration and related fields. However, applications from students across all study areas are very welcome. Students are encouraged to write in hybrid forms, across genres and within multiple art forms. The course is based on the belief that for today’s creators, a strong ability to TELL is essential in order to SHOW.

The programme opens with Watershed in the form of a ‘Camp’, guest lectures and workshops designed to get you out of your head and into the writing. Throughout the course, you will participate in guest talks, workshops and inspiration days developed together with Watershed, taking place on-site, online and/or off-site. There is a strong focus on the value of group dynamics for individual work, so be prepared to work closely with others. This practice is built on the understanding that media creation is a collective experience.

During the minor, you will develop a media (mixed or hybrid) project with writing as its foundation. With guidance, you will choose the form that best suits your theme, material and goals. The forms are open, and you will learn which medium best supports your story (such as podcasts, chapbooks, graphic novels, short stories in video, and more).

description: The minor programme Performance Art is an in-depth programme for visual artists and performing artists who see themselves and/or their bodies as an essential part of the artwork. The programme is set up as an academic/artistic workshop in which the individual artist’s question forms the starting point for researching the possibilities of the self/body in performance.
